Requirements for In-band OAM Requirements for In-situ OAM
draft-brockners-inband-oam-requirements-01 draft-brockners-inband-oam-requirements-02
Abstract Abstract
This document discusses the motivation and requirements for including This document discusses the motivation and requirements for including
specific operational and telemetry information into data packets specific operational and telemetry information into data packets
while the data packet traverses a path between two points in the while the data packet traverses a path between two points in the
network. This method is referred to as "in-band" Operations, network. This method is referred to as "in-situ" Operations,
Administration, and Maintenance (OAM), given that the OAM information Administration, and Maintenance (OAM), given that the OAM information
is carried with the data packets as opposed to in "out-of-band" is carried with the data packets as opposed to in "out-of-band"
packets dedicated to OAM. In-band OAM complements other OAM packets dedicated to OAM. In situ OAM complements other OAM
mechanisms which use dedicated probe packets to convey OAM mechanisms which use dedicated probe packets to convey OAM
information. information.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
This document discusses requirements for "in-band" Operations, This document discusses requirements for "in-situ" Operations,
Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) mechanisms. "In-band" OAM Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) mechanisms. In this context,
means to record OAM and telemetry information within the data packet "in-situ OAM" refers to the concept of directly encoding telemetry
while the data packet traverses a network or a particular network information within the data packet as it traverses the network or
domain. The term "in-band" refers to the fact that the OAM and telemetry domain. Mechanisms which add tracing or other types of
telemetry data is carried within data packets rather than being sent telemetry information to the regular data traffic, sometimes also
within packets specifically dedicated to OAM. In-band OAM referred to as "in-band" OAM can complement active, probe-based
mechanisms, which are sometimes also referred to as embedded network mechanisms such as ping or traceroute, which are sometimes considered
telemetry are a current topic of discussion. In-band network as "out-of-band", because the messages are transported independently
telemetry has been defined for P4 [P4]. The SPUD prototype from regular data traffic. In terms of "active" or "passive" OAM,
[I-D.hildebrand-spud-prototype] uses a similar logic that allows "in-situ" OAM can be considered a hybrid OAM type. While no extra
network devices on the path between endpoints to participate packets are sent, in-situ OAM adds information to the packets
explicitly in the tube outside the end-to-end context. Even the IPv4 therefore cannot be considered passive. In terms of the
route-record option defined in [RFC0791] can be considered an in-band classification given in [RFC7799] in-situ OAM could be portrayed as
OAM mechanism. In-band OAM complements "out-of-band" mechanisms such "hybrid OAM, type 1". "In-situ" mechanisms do not require extra
packets to be sent and hence don't change the packet traffic mix
within the network. Traceroute and ping for example use ICMP
messages: New packets are injected to get tracing information. Those
add to the number of messages in a network, which already might be
highly loaded or suffering performance issues for a particular path
or traffic type.
A number of in-situ as well as in-band OAM mechanisms have been
discussed, such as the INT spec for the P4 programming language [P4]
or the SPUD prototype [I-D.hildebrand-spud-prototype]. The SPUD
prototype uses a similar logic that allows network devices on the
path between endpoints to participate explicitly in the tube outside
the end-to-end context. Even the IPv4 route-record option defined in
[RFC0791] can be considered an in-situ OAM mechanism. Per what was
already stated, in-situ OAM complements "out-of-band" mechanisms such
as ping or traceroute, or more recent active probing mechanisms, as as ping or traceroute, or more recent active probing mechanisms, as
described in [I-D.lapukhov-dataplane-probe]. In-band OAM mechanisms described in [I-D.lapukhov-dataplane-probe]. In-situ OAM mechanisms
can be leveraged where current out-of-band mechanisms do not apply or can be leveraged where current out-of-band mechanisms do not apply or
do not offer the desired characteristics or requirements, such as do not offer the desired characteristics or requirements, such as
proving that a certain set of traffic takes a pre-defined path, proving that a certain set of traffic takes a pre-defined path,
strict congruency is desired, checking service level agreements for strict congruency between overlay and underlay transports is in
the live data traffic, detailed statistics on traffic distribution place, checking service level agreements for the live data traffic,
paths in networks that distribute traffic across multiple paths, or detailed statistics or verification of path selections within a
scenarios where probe traffic is potentially handled differently from domain, or scenarios where probe traffic is potentially handled
regular data traffic by the network devices. [RFC7276] presents an differently from regular data traffic by the network devices.
overview of OAM tools. [RFC7276] presents an overview of OAM tools.
Compared to probably the most basic example of "in-band OAM" which is Compared to probably the most basic example of "in-situ OAM" which is
IPv4 route recording [RFC0791], an in-band OAM approach has the IPv4 route recording [RFC0791], an in-situ OAM approach has the
following capabilities: following capabilities:
a. A flexible data format to allow different types of information to a. A flexible data format to allow different types of information to
be captured as part of an in-band OAM operation, including not be captured as part of an in-situ OAM operation, including but
only path tracing information, but additional operational and not limited to path tracing information, operational and
telemetry information such as timestamps, sequence numbers, or telemetry information such as timestamps, sequence numbers, or
even generic data such as queue size, geo-location of the node even generic data such as queue size, geo-location of the node
that forwarded the packet, etc. that forwarded the packet, etc.
b. A data format to express node as well as link identifiers to b. A data format to express node as well as link identifiers to
record the path a packet takes with a fixed amount of added data. record the path a packet takes with a fixed amount of added data.
c. The ability to detect whether any nodes were skipped while c. The ability to determine whether any nodes were skipped while
recording in-band OAM information (i.e., in-band OAM is not recording in-situ OAM information (i.e., in-situ OAM is not
supported or not enabled on those nodes). supported or not enabled on those nodes).
d. The ability to actively process information in the packet, for d. The ability to actively process information in the packet, for
example to prove in a cryptographically secure way that a packet example to prove in a cryptographically secure way that a packet
really took a pre-defined path using some traffic steering method really took a pre-defined path using some traffic steering method
such as service chaining or traffic engineering. such as service chaining or traffic engineering.
e. The ability to include OAM data beyond simple path information, e. The ability to include OAM data beyond simple path information,
such as timestamps or even generic data of a particular use case. such as timestamps or even generic data of a particular use case.

This document defines in-band Operations, Administration, and This document defines in-situ Operations, Administration, and
Maintenance (in-band OAM), as the subset in which OAM information is Maintenance (in-situ OAM), as the subset in which OAM information is
carried along with data packets. This is as opposed to "out-of-band carried along with data packets. This is as opposed to "out-of-band
OAM", where specific packets are dedicated to carrying OAM OAM", where specific packets are dedicated to carrying OAM
information. information.
3. Motivation for In-band OAM 3. Motivation for in-situ OAM
In several scenarios it is beneficial to make information about which In several scenarios it is beneficial to make information about the
path a packet took through the network available to the operator. path a packet took through the network or through a network device as
well as associated telemetry information available to the operator.
This includes not only tasks like debugging, troubleshooting, as well This includes not only tasks like debugging, troubleshooting, as well
as network planning and network optimization but also policy or as network planning and network optimization but also policy or
service level agreement compliance checks. This section discusses service level agreement compliance checks. This section discusses
the motivation to introduce new methods for enhanced in-band network the motivation to introduce new methods for enhanced in-situ network
diagnostics. diagnostics.
3.1. Path Congruency Issues with Dedicated OAM Packets 3.1. Path Congruency Issues with Dedicated OAM Packets
Mechanisms which add tracing information to the regular data traffic,
sometimes also referred to as "in-band" or "passive OAM" can
complement active, probe-based mechanisms such as ping or traceroute,
which are sometimes considered as "out-of-band", because the messages
are transported independently from regular data traffic. "In-band"
mechanisms do not require extra packets to be sent and hence don't
change the packet traffic mix within the network. Traceroute and
ping for example use ICMP messages: New packets are injected to get
tracing information. Those add to the number of messages in a
network, which already might be highly loaded or suffering
performance issues for a particular path or traffic type.
Packet scheduling algorithms, especially for balancing traffic across Packet scheduling algorithms, especially for balancing traffic across
equal cost paths or links, often leverage information contained equal cost paths or links, often leverage information contained
within the packet, such as protocol number, IP-address or MAC- within the packet, such as protocol number, IP-address or MAC-
address. Probe packets would thus either need to be sent from the address. Probe packets would thus either need to be sent from the
exact same endpoints with the exact same parameters, or probe packets exact same endpoints with the exact same parameters, or probe packets
would need to be artificially constructed as "fake" packets and would need to be artificially constructed as "fake" packets and
inserted along the path. Both approaches are often not feasible from inserted along the path. Both approaches are often not feasible from
an operational perspective, be it that access to the end-system is an operational perspective, be it that access to the end-system is
not feasible, or that the diversity of parameters and associated not feasible, or that the diversity of parameters and associated
probe packets to be created is simply too large. An in-band probe packets to be created is simply too large. An in-situ
mechanism is an alternative in those cases. mechanism is an alternative in those cases.
In-band mechanisms also don't suffer from implementations, where In-situ mechanisms are not impacted by differences in the handling of
probe traffic is handled differently (and potentially forwarded probe traffic compared to other data packets, where probe traffic is
differently) by a router than regular data traffic. handled differently (and potentially forwarded differently) by a
router than regular data traffic. This obviously assumes that the
addition of in-situ information does not change the forwarding
behavior of the packet. Note that in certain implementations, the
addition information to a transport protocol changes the forwarding
behavior. IPv6 extension header processing is one example. Some
implementations process IPv6 packets with extension headers in the
"slow" path of a router, as opposed to the "fast" path.
3.2. Results Sent to a System Other Than the Sender 3.2. Results Sent to a System Other Than the Sender
Traditional ping and traceroute tools return the OAM results to the Traditional ping and traceroute tools return the OAM results to the
sender of the probe. Even when the ICMP messages that are used with sender of the probe. Even when the ICMP messages that are used with
these tools are enhanced, and additional telemetry is collected these tools are enhanced, and additional telemetry is collected
(e.g., ICMP Multi-Part [RFC4884] supporting MPLS information (e.g., ICMP Multi-Part [RFC4884] supporting MPLS information
[RFC4950], Interface and Next-Hop Identification [RFC5837], etc.), it [RFC4950], Interface and Next-Hop Identification [RFC5837], etc.), it
would be advantageous to separate the sending of an OAM probe from would be advantageous to separate the sending of an OAM probe from
the receiving of the telemetry data. In this context, it is desired the receiving of the telemetry data. In this context, it is helpful
to not assume there is a bidirectional working path. to eliminate the requirement that there be a working bidirectional
path.
3.3. Overlay and Underlay Correlation 3.3. Overlay and Underlay Correlation
Several network deployments leverage tunneling mechanisms to create Several network deployments leverage tunneling mechanisms to create
overlay or service-layer networks. Examples include VXLAN-GPE, GRE, overlay or service-layer networks. Examples include VXLAN-GPE, GRE,
or LISP. One often observed attribute of overlay networks is that or LISP. One often observed attribute of overlay networks is that
they do not offer the user of the overlay any insight into the they do not offer the user of the overlay any insight into the
underlay network. This means that the path that a particular underlay network. This means that the path that a particular
tunneled packet takes, nor other operational details such as the per- tunneled packet takes, nor other operational details such as the per-
hop delay/jitter in the underlay are visible to the user of the hop delay/jitter in the underlay are visible to the user of the
overlay network, giving rise to diagnosis and debugging challenges in overlay network, giving rise to diagnosis and debugging challenges in
case of connectivity or performance issues. The scope of OAM tools case of connectivity or performance issues. The scope of OAM tools
like ping or traceroute is limited to either the overlay or the like ping or traceroute is limited to either the overlay or the
underlay which means that the user of the overlay has typically no underlay which means that the user of the overlay has typically no
access to OAM in the underlay, unless specific operational procedures access to OAM in the underlay, unless specific operational procedures
are put in place. With in-band OAM the operator of the underlay can are put in place. With in-situ OAM the operator of the underlay can
offer details of the connectivity in the underlay to the user of the offer details of the connectivity in the underlay to the user of the
overlay. The operator of the egress tunnel router could choose to overlay. This could include the ability to find out which underlay
share the recorded information about the path with the user of the elements are shared by overlays and ability to know which overlays
overlay. are mapped to the same underlay elements. Deployment dependent
underlay transit nodes can be configured to update OAM information in
the overlay transport encapsulation. The operator of the egress
tunnel router could choose to share the recorded information about
the path with the user of the overlay.
Coupled with mechanisms such as Segment Routing (SR) Coupled with mechanisms such as Segment Routing (SR)
[I-D.ietf-spring-segment-routing], overlay network and underlay [I-D.ietf-spring-segment-routing], overlay network and underlay
network can be more tightly coupled: The user of the overlay has network can be more tightly coupled: The user of the overlay has
detailed diagnostic information available in case of failure detailed diagnostic information available in case of failure
conditions. The user of the overlay can also use the path recording conditions. The user of the overlay can also use the path recording
information as input to traffic steering or traffic engineering information as input to traffic steering or traffic engineering
mechanisms, to for example achieve path symmetry for the traffic mechanisms, to for example achieve path symmetry for the traffic
between two endpoints. [I-D.brockners-lisp-sr] is an example for how between two endpoints. [I-D.brockners-lisp-sr] is an example for how
these methods can be applied to LISP. these methods can be applied to LISP.
3.4. SLA Verification 3.4. SLA Verification
In-band OAM can help users of an overlay-service to verify that In-situ OAM can help users of an overlay-service to verify that
negotiated SLAs for the real traffic are met by the underlay network negotiated SLAs for the real traffic are met by the underlay network
provider. Different from solutions which rely on active probes to provider. Different from solutions which rely on active probes to
test an SLA, in-band OAM based mechanisms avoid wrong interpretations test an SLA, in-situ OAM based mechanisms avoid wrong interpretations
and "cheating", which can happen if the probe traffic that is used to and "cheating", which can happen if the probe traffic that is used to
perform SLA-check is prioritized by the network provider of the perform SLA-check is prioritized by the network provider of the
underlay. underlay. In active/standby deployments in-situ OAM would only allow
for SLA verification of the active path.
3.5. Analytics and Diagnostics 3.5. Analytics and Diagnostics
Network planners and operators benefit from knowledge of the actual Network planners and operators benefit from knowledge of the actual
traffic distribution in the network. When deriving an overall traffic distribution in the network. When deriving an overall
network connectivity traffic matrix one typically needs to correlate network connectivity traffic matrix one typically needs to correlate
data gathered from each individual devices in the network. If the data gathered from each individual device in the network. If the
path of a packet is recorded while the packet is forwarded, the path of a packet is recorded while the packet is forwarded, the
entire path that a packet took through the network is available to entire path that a packet took through the network is available to
the egress system. This obviates the need to retrieve individual the egress system. This obviates the need to retrieve individual
traffic statistics from every device in the network and correlate traffic statistics from every device in the network and correlate
those statistics, or employ other mechanisms such as leveraging those statistics, or employ other mechanisms such as leveraging
traffic engineering with null-bandwidth tunnels just to retrieve the traffic engineering with null-bandwidth tunnels just to retrieve the
appropriate statistics to generate the traffic matrix. appropriate statistics to generate the traffic matrix.
In addition, with individual path tracing, information is available In addition, with individual path tracing, information is available
at packet level granularity, rather than only at aggregate level - as at packet level granularity, rather than only at aggregate level - as
is usually the case with IPFIX-style methods which employ flow- is usually the case with IPFIX-style methods which employ flow-
filters at the network elements. Data-center networks which use filters at the network elements. Data-center networks which use
equal-cost multipath (ECMP) forwarding are one example where detailed equal-cost multipath (ECMP) forwarding are one example where detailed
statistics on flow distribution in the network are highly desired. statistics on flow distribution in the network are highly desired.
If a network supports ECMP, one can create detailed statistics for If a network supports ECMP, one can create detailed statistics for
the different paths packets take through the network at the egress the different paths packets take through the network at the egress
system, without a need to correlate/aggregate statistics from every system, without a need to correlate/aggregate statistics from every
router in the system. Transit devices are off-loaded from the task router in the system. Transit devices are off-loaded from the task
of gathering packet statistics. of gathering packet statistics.
In high-speed networks one can leverage and benefit from packet-
accurate measurements with for example hardware-accurate timestamping
(i.e., nanosecond-level verification) to support optimized packet
scheduling and queuing mechanisms.
3.6. Frame Replication/Elimination Decision for Bi-casting/Active- 3.6. Frame Replication/Elimination Decision for Bi-casting/Active-
active Networks active Networks
Bandwidth- and power-constrained, time-sensitive, or loss-intolerant Bandwidth- and power-constrained, time-sensitive, or loss-intolerant
networks (e.g., networks for industry automation/control, health networks (e.g., networks for industry automation/control, health
care) require efficient OAM methods to decide when to replicate care) require efficient OAM methods to decide when to replicate
packets to a secondary path in order to keep the loss/error-rate for packets to a secondary path in order to keep the loss/error-rate for
the receiver at a tolerable level - and also when to stop replication the receiver at a tolerable level - and also when to stop replication
and eliminate the redundant flow. Many IoT networks are time and eliminate the redundant flow. Many Internet of Things (IoT)
sensitive and cannot leverage automatic retransmission requests (ARQ) networks are time sensitive and cannot leverage automatic
to cope with transmission errors or lost packets. Transmitting the retransmission requests (ARQ) to cope with transmission errors or
data over multiple disparate paths (often called bi-casting or live- lost packets. Transmitting the data over multiple disparate paths
live) is a method used to reduce the error rate observed by the (often called bi-casting or live-live) is a method used to reduce the
receiver. TSN receive a lot of attention from the manufacturing error rate observed by the receiver. Time sensitive networks (TSN)
industry as shown by a various standardization activities and receive a lot of attention from the manufacturing industry as shown
industry forums being formed (see e.g., IETF 6TiSCH, IEEE P802.1CB, by a various standardization activities and industry forums being
AVnu). formed (see e.g., IETF 6TiSCH, IEEE P802.1CB, AVnu).
3.7. Proof of Transit 3.7. Proof of Transit
Several deployments use traffic engineering, policy routing, segment Several deployments use traffic engineering, policy routing, segment
routing or Service Function Chaining (SFC) [RFC7665] to steer packets routing or Service Function Chaining (SFC) [RFC7665] to steer packets

4. Considerations for In-band OAM o Device-level troubleshooting and optimization: In many cases,
network operators could benefit from information specific to a
single device. A non-exhaustive list of useful information
includes: queue-depths, buffer utilization (either shared or per-
port), packet latency measured from a known starting point, packet
latency introduced by a single device, and resource utilization
(CPU, memory, link bandwidth) of a given device or link. In some
cases, this information changes over per-packet timescales (i.e.,
nanoseconds) and as such it is extremely challenging to collect
and report this info in an accurate and scalable manner. By
encoding the information from the forwarding element directly
within a data packet (i.e., within the 'fast-path') this
information can be added to some or all data packets and then
collected and analyzed by human or machine tools. This type of
information is particularly valuable for troubleshooting low-level
device errors as well as providing a knowledge feedback loop for
network and device optimization.
The implementation of an in-band OAM mechanism needs to take several o Custom network probing: Active network probing and in-situ OAM can
be combined for customized and efficient network probing. This
could for example be a customized traceroute.
4. Considerations for In-situ OAM

considerations into account, including administrative boundaries, how considerations into account, including administrative boundaries, how
information is recorded, Maximum Transfer Unit (MTU), Path MTU information is recorded, Maximum Transfer Unit (MTU), Path MTU
discovery and packet size, etc. discovery and packet size, etc.

to the edges of a domain, such as sequence numbers. the edges of a domain, such as sequence numbers. Note that a single
network device could comprise several in-situ OAM hops, for example
in case one wants to trace the path of a packet through that device.

network edges (the "edge" of a network could either be a host or a network edges (the "edge" of a network could either be a host or a
domain edge device): Edge to edge data e.g., packet and octet domain edge device): Edge to edge data e.g., packet and octet
count of data entering a well-defined domain and leaving it is count of data entering a well-defined domain and leaving it is

4.2. MTU and packet size 4.2. MTU and Packet Size
The recorded data at every hop may lead to packet size exceeding the The recorded data at every hop might lead to packet size exceeding
Maximum Transmit Unit (MTU). Based on the transport protocol used the Maximum Transmit Unit (MTU). A detailed discussion of the
MTU is discovered as a configuration parameter or Path MTU (PMTU) is implications of oversized IPv6 header chains is found in [RFC7112].
discovered dynamically. Example: IPv6 recommends PMTU discovery
before data packets are sent to prevent packet fragmentation. It
specifies 1280 octets as the default PDU to be carried in a IPv6
datagram. A detailed discussion of the implications of oversized
IPv6 header chains if found in [RFC7112].
The Path MTU restricts the amount of data that can be recorded for The Path MTU restricts the amount of data that can be recorded for
purpose of OAM within a data packet. The total size of data to be purpose of OAM within a data packet.
recorded needs to be preset to avoid packet size exceeding the MTU.
It is recommended to pre-calculate and configures network devices to If in-situ OAM data is inserted at the edge of the domain (e.g., by
limit the in-band OAM data that is attached to a packet. intermediate routers) then the MTU on all interfaces with the domain
(MTU_INT) MUST be >= the maximum MTU on any "external" facing
interfaces (MTU_EXT) and the total size of in-situ OAM data to be
recorded MUST be <= (MTU_INT - MTU_EXT).
4.3. Administrative boundaries In-situ OAM comprises two approaches to insert OAM data-records in
the packets:
There are several challenges in enabling in-band OAM in the public o Pre-allocated: In this case, the encapsulating node inserts empty
data records into the packet to cover the entire domain. The data
records will be incrementally updated/filled as the packet
progresses through the network. With pre-allocation the packet
size is only changed at the encapsulating node and is kept
constant throughout the domain. The pre-allocated approach is
beneficial for software data-plane implementations where
allocating the required space only once and index into the array
to populate the data during transit avoids copy operations at
every hop.
o Incremental: Every node that desires to include in-situ OAM
information extends the packet as needed. The incremental
approach is beneficial for hardware data-plane implementations as
it eliminates the need for the transit nodes to read the full
array and lookup the pointer in the option prior to updating the
data record contents.
The "incremental" or the "pre-allocated" approaches could even be
combined in the same deployment - in which case two in-situ OAM
headers would be present in the packet: One for the incremental
approach and one for the pre-allocated approach. In such a case one
would expect that nodes with a hardware data-plane would update the
incremental header, whereas nodes with a software data-plane would
process the pre-allocated header.
4.3. Administrative Boundaries
There are several challenges in enabling in-situ OAM in the public
Internet as well as in corporate/enterprise networks across Internet as well as in corporate/enterprise networks across
administrative domains, which include but are not limited to: administrative domains, which include but are not limited to:
o Deployment dependent, the data fields that in-band OAM requires as o Deployment dependent, the data fields that in-situ OAM requires as
part of a specific transport protocol may not be supported across part of a specific transport protocol may not be supported across
administrative boundaries. administrative boundaries.
o Current OAM implementations are often done in the slow path, i.e., o Current OAM implementations are often done in the slow path, i.e.,
OAM packets are punted to router's CPU for processing. This leads OAM packets are punted to router's CPU for processing. This leads
to performance and scaling issues and opens up routers for attacks to performance and scaling issues and opens up routers for attacks
such as Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. such as Denial of Service (DoS) attacks.
o Discovery of network topology and details of the network devices o Discovery of network topology and details of the network devices
across administrative boundaries may open up attack vectors across administrative boundaries may open up attack vectors
compromising network security. compromising network security.
o Specifically on IPv6: At the administrative boundaries IPv6 o Specifically on IPv6: At the administrative boundaries IPv6
packets with extension headers are dropped for several reasons packets with extension headers are dropped for several reasons
described in [RFC7872]. described in [RFC7872].

6. Security Considerations and Requirements 6. Security Considerations and Requirements
General Security considerations will be addressed in a later version 6.1. General considerations
of this document. Security considerations for Proof of Transit alone
are discussed below.
6.1. Proof of Transit General Security considerations will be expanded on in a later
version of this document.
In-situ OAM is considered a "per domain" feature, where one or
several operators decide on leveraging and configuring in-situ OAM
according to their needs. Still operators need to properly secure
the in-situ OAM domain to avoid malicious configuration and use,
which could include injecting malicious in-situ OAM packets into a
domain.
6.2. Proof of Transit
Threat Model: Attacks on the deployments could be due to malicious Threat Model: Attacks on the deployments could be due to malicious
administrators or accidental misconfigurations resulting in bypassing administrators or accidental misconfiguration resulting in bypassing
of certain nodes. The solution approach should meet the following of certain nodes. The solution approach should meet the following
requirements: requirements:
REQ-SEC1: Sound Proof of Transit: A valid and verifiable proof that REQ-SEC1: Sound Proof of Transit: A valid and verifiable proof that
the packet definitively traversed through all the nodes as the packet definitively traversed through all the nodes as
expected. Probabilistic methods to achieve this should be expected. Probabilistic methods to achieve this should be
avoided, as the same could be exploited by an attacker. avoided, as the same could be exploited by an attacker.
REQ-SEC2: Tampering of meta data: An active attacker should not be REQ-SEC2: Tampering of meta data: An active attacker should not be
able to insert or modify or delete meta data in whole or able to insert or modify or delete meta data in whole or
in parts and bypass few (or all) nodes. Any deviation in parts and bypass few (or all) nodes. Any deviation
from the expected path should be accurately determined. from the expected path should be accurately determined.
REQ-SEC3: Replay Attacks: A attacker (active/passive) should not be REQ-SEC3: Replay Attacks: A attacker (active/passive) should not be
able to reuse the proof of transit bits in the packet by able to reuse the POT bits in the packet by observing the
observing the OAM data in the packet, packet OAM data in the packet, packet characteristics (like IP
characteristics (like IP addresses, octets transferred, addresses, octets transferred, timestamps) or even the
timestamps) or even the proof bits themselves. The proof bits themselves. The solution approach should
solution approach should consider usage of these consider usage of these parameters for deriving any
parameters for deriving any secrets cautiously. secrets cautiously. Mitigating replay attacks beyond a
Mitigating replay attacks beyond a window of longer window of longer duration could be intractable to achieve
duration could be intractable to achieve with fixed number with fixed number of bits allocated for proof.
of bits allocated for proof.
